VirtPTR.PROJECT: Virtuoso uses '\' as universal escape character for strings
VirtPTR.COMMENTS:
Problem reported by Enterworks (SPR 4159):
OpenLink assumes that the '\' character is an escape character for all strings. This means that if you want to insert a '\' into a text field, you would have to escape it ('\\'). This would impact ECI when doing data migrations into tables stored in OpenLink, because ECI would have to know to escape all occurances of the '\' character before inserting the data into the table. This syntax is required even in escape strings. Example: select * from <table> where not <column> like '%\_%' escape '\' Would have to be written as follows in order to work with OpenLink: select * from <table> where not <column> like '%\\_%' escape '\\'
To recreate:
Attempt to insert the following string into an OpenLink table: 'My file is at d:\temp' Now query the table and note that the data returned is this: 'My file is at d:temp'
George: Generally the SQL Parser does expand backspace escaped characher on parsing the input string. That's why if you do : SQLExecDirect (..., "insert into some_table (char_data) values ('d:\data1')", SQL_NTS) it would parse the \ and the result would be "d:data1" stored in the coulmn. But if you do bind the value as in "insert into some_table (char_data) values (?)" and you bind 'd:\data1' as a input parameter to the command you'll get the correct values. I've prepared a small shell script to demonstrate the use of the ISQL's command FOREACH LINE (witch does bind it's values as parameters) to demonstrate this. Otherwise the LIKE predicate supports the syntax LIKE x ESCAPE y, but doesn't actually use the value supplied by ESCAPE.

VirtPTR.PROJECT: Virtuoso keeps open connections to databases
VirtPTR.COMMENTS:
Enterworks (SPR 4107):
Description: OpenLink keeps alive connections to all databases that have been queried. (E.g. it does not close the connection after the query has been completed). This can cause problems because it will prevent actions that require exclusive rights to the database. Such things could include renaming the database, dropping the database, etc. Reproduced: Always Steps to Reproduce: Make a query to a database table using OpenLink attempt to drop the database in the data source verify that the database was not dropped because it was in use
Orri has indicated we will implement a timeout feature to enable the time connections are held open to be configured. George: timeout implemented

VirtPTR.PROJECT: Next query will fail if data source connection is lost
VirtPTR.COMMENTS:
Enterworks (SPR 4104):
Description: If an OpenLink server looses it's Data Source connection, the next query to that data source will fail, even if the data source is running correctly. OpenLink seems to keep a connection open to each of it's data sources, and if one of the connections is lost for some reason, it is not smart enough to realize this and re-establish the connection when the next query to that data source comes in. The query will fail but the next query that comes in to that data source will succeed. Reproduced: Always Steps to Reproduce: Link a table to an Omni server. Do a query to the table. Using Sybase Central, find the connection being used by the OpenLink server and delete it. Do a query to the table, and note that it failed. Do another query to the table, and note that it succeeded.
Orri has indicated that we will provide a fix for this. George: The server VDB now retries 1 time before returning an error

VirtPTR.COMMENTS: Steps to Reproduce: ECI needs to be using OpenLink Virtuoso/EDS as its data server. The testing for this was done on Virtuoso version 1947 on Solaris OS 2.7. The Solaris machine (penguin) has 4 processors. To test from ECI, set the target data server to a virtuoso/openlink server. Then do the query as above. What is special about this query is that it is a union of queries against web tables, and it has an aggregate function. The combination causes the subqueries to be executed concurrently, insert-selecting the results into a local "scratch" table on the data server. But the crash actually occurs earlier, as each subquery is attempting to put the web results into a local "scratch" table. So there are three concurrent threads, each of which is creating its own local table and insert-values of rows into it. The test described above will encounter problems much of the time, although it will sometimes succeed. When it succeeds, it tends to do so many times in a row. When it fails, it tends to do so many many times in a row. Cannot figure out an exact pattern. Virtuoso does not core dump every time there is a failure, but it does core dump a significant amount of the time. The error messages and core dumping of virtuoso can be reliably reproduced using a script which invokes three isql batch sessions, putting each into the background. Each isql script creates a table and inserts rows into it. See /home/ellersk/virtuoso/scripts/testcrash for the example. I ran these scripts against a Virtuoso on NT, but it did not crash. However, the NT machine I tried it on has only one processor. Have not tested from ECI on NT.
